1em!important;width:auto!important}div#onetrust-consent-sdk button:hover{background-color:#fff!important;border-color:#eb6500!important;color:#2e2e2e!important}div#onetrust-consent-sdk However, integrating nanocrystal heterojunctions into a conductive layer to form a superstructure is a significant challenge, mainly due to the difficulty in maintaining the structural integrity. Here we report a unique glucose-induced heterogeneous nucleation method that enables the independent manipulation of nucleation and growth of Mo"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"C/MoC heterojunction nanocrystals within 2D layers. Our investigations reveal that the rGO-Mo"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"C/MoC-rGO superstructure is formed by a topological transformation induced by subsequent heat treatment of the initial hydrothermally prepared rGO-MoO"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"-rGO precursor. This novel structure embeds Mo"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"C/MoC heterojunction nanocrystals within a 2D graphene matrix, providing enhanced mechanical stability, accelerated Na"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"sup","_":"+"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" transport, and improved electron conduction. "},{"#name":"italic","_":"Ex situ"},{"#name":"__text__","_":" XRD and Raman spectroscopy analyses reveal that the rGO-Mo"},{"$":{"loc":"post"},"#name":"inf","_":"2"},{"#name":"__text__","_":"C/MoC-rGO superstructure significantly enhances the stability and reversibility of anodes. Leveraging these unique characteristics, the newly developed superstructural anode exhibits remarkable long-term cycling stability and outstanding rate performance. As a result, superstructure anodes demonstrate superior electrochemical capabilities, delivering a specific capacity of 106 mAh/g after enduring 5000 cycles at 1 A/g. Our study underscores the critical importance of superstructure design in propelling the advancement of battery materials."}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"sp0015"},"#name":"simple-para"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"as015"},"#name":"abstract-sec"}],"$":{"view":"all","id":"ab015","class":"author"},"#name":"abstract"}],"floats":[],"footnotes":[],"attachments":[{"attachment-eid":"1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-ga1.jpg","ucs-locator":"https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S0021979724019714/ga1/DOWNSAMPLED/image/jpeg/7c2f441302fcfb8a9797f024e70cccc2/ga1.jpg","file-basename":"ga1","abstract-attachment":"true","filename":"ga1.jpg","extension":"jpg","filesize":"27454","pixel-height":"200","pixel-width":"424","attachment-type":"IMAGE-DOWNSAMPLED"},{"attachment-eid":"1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-ga1.sml","ucs-locator":"https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S0021979724019714/ga1/THUMBNAIL/image/gif/3ce23b8c67faa3936a165d4a9e9be8ee/ga1.sml","file-basename":"ga1","abstract-attachment":"true","filename":"ga1.sml","extension":"sml","filesize":"9380","pixel-height":"103","pixel-width":"219","attachment-type":"IMAGE-THUMBNAIL"},{"attachment-eid":"1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-ga1_lrg.jpg","ucs-locator":"https://s3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/prod-ucs-content-store-eu-west/content/pii:S0021979724019714/HIGHRES/image/jpeg/4625c98fecff8a5e511a7d3d18631dbc/ga1_lrg.jpg","file-basename":"ga1","abstract-attachment":"true","filename":"ga1_lrg.jpg","extension":"jpg","filesize":"157440","pixel-height":"886","pixel-width":"1878","attachment-type":"IMAGE-HIGH-RES"}]},"accessbarConfig":{"fallback":false,"id":"accessbar","version":"0.0.1","analytics":{"location":"accessbar","eventName":"ctaImpression"},"label":{},"ariaLabel":{"accessbar":"Download publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2024.08.188" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2024.08.188</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="ab010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="as010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0005">A confined Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC heterojunction nanocrystal-graphene superstructure anode was proposed.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">A unique glucose-induced heterogeneous nucleation method was presented.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">The electrochemical reaction mechanism in superstructure anodes was revealed.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="ab015"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Heterostructure design and integration with conductive materials play a crucial role in enhancing the conversion kinetics of electrode materials for metal-ion batteries. However, integrating nanocrystal heterojunctions into a conductive layer to form a superstructure is a significant challenge, mainly due to the difficulty in maintaining the structural integrity. Here we report a unique glucose-induced heterogeneous nucleation method that enables the independent manipulation of nucleation and growth of Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC heterojunction nanocrystals within 2D layers. Our investigations reveal that the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO superstructure is formed by a topological transformation induced by subsequent heat treatment of the initial hydrothermally prepared rGO-MoO<sub>2</sub>-rGO precursor. This novel structure embeds Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC heterojunction nanocrystals within a 2D graphene matrix, providing enhanced mechanical stability, accelerated Na<sup>+</sup> transport, and improved electron conduction. <em>Ex situ</em> XRD and Raman spectroscopy analyses reveal that the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO superstructure significantly enhances the stability and reversibility of anodes. Leveraging these unique characteristics, the newly developed superstructural anode exhibits remarkable long-term cycling stability and outstanding rate performance. As a result, superstructure anodes demonstrate superior electrochemical capabilities, delivering a specific capacity of 106&nbsp;mAh/g after enduring 5000 cycles at 1 A/g. Our study underscores the critical importance of superstructure design in propelling the advancement of battery materials.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0005"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0050"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt=""><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (154KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (154KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724019829"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724019635"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>Molybdenum carbide</span></div><div id="k0010" class="keyword"><span>Anodes</span></div><div id="k0015" class="keyword"><span>Heterojunction</span></div><div id="k0020" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div id="k0025" class="keyword"><span>Graphene</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are considered as strong contenders for the next generation of energy storage devices, with the potential to rival or even replace current lithium-ion batteries due to the abundance and low cost of sodium resources <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>. However, there are differences in the electrochemical properties between Na<sup>+</sup> and Li<sup>+</sup>, such as the electrochemical standard potential of Na<sup>+</sup>/Na (−2.71&nbsp;V) higher than that of Li<sup>+</sup>/Li (−3.04&nbsp;V), and the larger atomic mass and ionic radius of Na<sup>+</sup>, which lead to lower energy density and poorer cycle stability of SIBs <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>. Accordingly, the key to technological breakthroughs in SIBs lies in the development of new electrode materials, especially anode materials.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0030">In this context, transition metal carbides (TMCs) can be considered an intriguing group of materials due to their ability to store charge through both non-Faradaically and Faradaically, their highly conductive structures characterized by carbon atoms interspersed within the voids of the transition metal framework, as well as their beneficial properties, including chemical and mechanical stability and a wealth of catalytic active sites <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>. These advantages of TMCs lead to rapid charge response, thereby reinforcing their potential as high-performance electrode materials <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>. In the pursuit of enhancing the kinetic performance of electrodes, contemporary research has implemented several pivotal strategies (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0045" name="bf0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Scheme. 1</span></span></a>a). For example, the conversion of active materials into nanocrystals has markedly improved their reactivity <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>. To address the inherent poor conductivity of nanocrystals, researchers have typically employed a compounding approach, integrating active materials with conductive ones to fabricate composites possessing superior electrical conductivity <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>. Meticulous control over the morphologies of electrode materials has led to enhanced structural characteristics <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>. Utilizing the physical principles of heterojunction structures, uniquely advantageous heterostructured active materials have been developed <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>. These strategies are of great significance in developing high-performance anode materials.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0045"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr9.jpg" height="319" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0045"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr9_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (349KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (349KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr9.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0045"><p id="sp0060"><span class="label">Scheme 1</span>. <strong>Motivation and strategy for the preparation of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO superstructural anodes.</strong> (a) Traditional anode design VS (b) Superlattice anode design.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035">The design and synthesis of Mo<sub>2</sub>C materials in recent years has thoroughly embraced these strategies. Across studies focusing on Oxygen Evolution Reaction (OER) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, the Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, and Lithium-Sulfur (Li-S) batteries <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, these design principles have demonstrated broad applicability and efficacy. However, a significant challenge remains: the active regions of the electrode may induce side reactions when in direct contact with the electrolyte during charge and discharge processes <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>. Furthermore, active materials risk detachment from the current collector due to stress alterations throughout the charge and discharge cycles, and Molybdenum-based anode materials are mainly faced with the issues of volume expansion and pulverization during charge and discharge processes <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>. Additionally, the interface between active and conductive substances lacks atomic-level contact, implying that, in theory, electrode designs have not yet achieved maximal utilization efficiency <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>. Consequently, there is an urgent need for future research to focus on further optimizing the structural design of electrode materials, thereby facilitating more efficient energy conversion and storage.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">It is well-known that the 2D superlattice structures exhibit significant application advantages in the field of energy storage due to their unique physical and chemical properties, such as high surface area and active sites, short ion diffusion paths, and atomic-level heterointerfaces. Currently, there is limited progress in the study of potential synergistic effects at the Mo<sub>2</sub>C heterostructure anode interface and superlattice surface.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045">In this work, we introduce a novel confined Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC nanocrystal heterojunction-graphene superstructure anode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0045" name="bf0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Scheme. 1</span></span></a>b). This unique structure encapsulates the Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC nanocrystal heterojunction between graphene layers, enhancing the mechanical strength of the electrode and promoting rapid Na<sup>+</sup> transfer, supplemented by enhanced electronic conductivity. This anode design fully utilizes the advantages of heterostructures and 2D conductive materials to enhance transformation kinetics. The experimental results show that this electrode exhibits impressive specific capacity and cycle stability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050">This study not only provides a new method for synthesizing Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC heterojunction nanocrystal superstructures, but also opens up new avenues for designing advanced anode materials for SIBs with significantly enhanced energy storage capacity.</div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental Section</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">Natural graphite (750–850 mesh, Aladdin), potassium peroxydisulfate (K<sub>2</sub>S<sub>2</sub>O<sub>8</sub>, Macklin), Sulfuric acid (98&nbsp;% H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>, Aladdin), Hydrochloric acid (38&nbsp;% HCl, Macklin), Potassium permanganatepre (KMnO<sub>4</sub>, Macklin), Hydrogen peroxide (30&nbsp;% H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, Aladdin), Hexaammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate ((NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>6</sub>Mo<sub>7</sub>O<sub>24</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O, Aladdin), Polyvinylpyrrolidone ((C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>9</sub>NO)n, Macklin), Glucose (C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O, Macklin), and Formic acid (88&nbsp;% HCOOH, Macklin)were used directly without further purification.</div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Preparation of graphene oxide (GO)</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060">The preparation of GO was accomplished from expanded graphite via an enhanced Hummers method <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>. Initially, a mixture of expandable graphite powder (2.0&nbsp;g) and K<sub>2</sub>S<sub>2</sub>O<sub>8</sub> (1.0&nbsp;g) was introduced into concentrated H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> (40&nbsp;mL) and agitated for 1&nbsp;h at 80°C. Afterwards, KMnO<sub>4</sub> (5.0&nbsp;g) was gradually introduced to the blend, maintaining the temperature below 35°C. The solution was agitated for another 2&nbsp;h. Next, 100&nbsp;mL of deionized water was added to it and the mixture was agitated for a further 20&nbsp;min.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065">Then, 30&nbsp;mL of H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (30&nbsp;%) was slowly introduced, leading to the formation of a saffron yellow suspension. The next process involved centrifugation with 6&nbsp;% HCI and deionized water (3&nbsp;min and 5000 r/min) until a neutral pH was achieved. After having undergone dialysis for 72&nbsp;h, the GO solution was finally ready for further applications.</div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Preparation of superstructural rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anodes</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070">Typically, 0.5&nbsp;g of PVP was added to an aqueous solution of formic acid and deionized water (1:3 vol/vol) under vigorous stirring for 30&nbsp;min. Subsequently, 0.5&nbsp;g of ammonium molybdate powder was added to the solution with vigorous stirring for 30&nbsp;min, followed by the addition of 1&nbsp;g of glucose and continued stirring for an additional 20&nbsp;min to form a homogenous mixture. Afterwards, the mixture solution was then slowly dropped into the GO suspensions after ultrasound at a slow rate, and the mixture was stirred for 6&nbsp;h to ensure complete dispersion of the components. The resultant suspension was transferred to a 100&nbsp;mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and held at 180&nbsp;°C for a duration of 12&nbsp;h. The resulting black precipitate was isolated by filtration, thoroughly washed with deionized water and ethanol, and dried at 40&nbsp;°C for 24&nbsp;h. Finally, the powders were annealed at 800&nbsp;°C for 2&nbsp;h under the N<sub>2</sub> atmosphere (5&nbsp;°C min<sup>−1</sup>) to obtain the desired Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC structured nanocomposites (rGO- Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO). The synthesis of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC mirrors that of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO, with the exception of glucose omission.</div></section><section id="s0030"><h3 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Materials characterizations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075">All specimens had their crystal structure data gathered by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Panaco Holland, Cu Kα radiation, λ&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.5406&nbsp;Å). The carbon structure and Mo-O vibration details of the samples were examined through Raman spectroscopy (JY HR800 Raman spectrometer, 532&nbsp;nm excitation). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha) was employed to inves- tigate the surface elemental composition and chemical environment of elements. Information relating to the sample's geometry was obtained using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Japan, JEOL JSM6300) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL, JEM-2010F). Characterization of the specific surface area and pore size distribution of these samples were conducted with N<sub>2</sub> adsorption at 77&nbsp;K (Quantachrome, NOVA-1200e). Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was performed in N<sub>2</sub>, heated at a rate of 10&nbsp;°C per minute ranging from room temperature up to 800&nbsp;°C using a thermal analyzer (STA 449F3, Netszch, Germany).</div></section><section id="s0035"><h3 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.5. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">Fabrication of the working electrode involved mixing anode material (70&nbsp;wt%), conductive agent (20&nbsp;wt%), and poly(vinylidene fluoride) as the binder (10&nbsp;wt%), with <em>N</em>-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) serving as the solvent. The prepared slurries were spread onto Cu foil and subjected to vacuum drying at 90 ℃ for 14&nbsp;h. The treated Cu foil was then formed into an electrode of 12 mm diameter using a press, setting the load of the active material on the electrode at 1.1&nbsp;mg. All cells were assembled inside an Ar-atmosphere glove box, using 1&nbsp;mol L<sup>-1</sup> NaClO<sub>4</sub> in a mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC): dimethyl carbonate (DMC): diethyl carbonate (EMC) at a ratio of 1:1:1&nbsp;vol% as the electrolyte. Sodium flakes served as the counter electrode. The galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) curves tests were conducted on a NEWARE multichannel battery testing system (NEWARE CT-4008) within a voltage window of 0.01–2.8&nbsp;V (against Na<sup>+</sup>/Na), and the specific capacity was determined based on the active material's mass. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) analysis was carried out on a CHI760E electrochemical workstation. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests spanned a frequency range from 0.01 to 10<sup>5</sup> Hz. The galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) was employed to measure Na<sup>+</sup> diffusivity during intercalation, and the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion coefficient in the electrode was calculated using equation <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0005" name="be0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(1)</span></span></a> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>E</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C4;</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup></mrow></math>"
