transform="translate(397,0)"><rect stroke="none" width="891" height="60" x="0" y="220"></rect><g is="true" transform="translate(268,403)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-34"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(60,-345)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(405,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C4"></use></g></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3294,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJSZ2-28"></use><g is="true" transform="translate(597,0)"><g is="true"><g transform="translate(120,0)"><rect stroke="none" width="2690" height="60" x="0" y="220"></rect><g is="true" transform="translate(60,509)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(621,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-42"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1071,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-56"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1615,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6D"></use></g><g is="true"></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(548,-403)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(686,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-42"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1136,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-53"></use></g></g></g></g></g><use xlink:href="#MJSZ2-29" x="3527" y="-1"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4125,877)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(7873,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJSZ2-28"></use><g is="true" transform="translate(597,0)"><g is="true"><g transform="translate(120,0)"><rect stroke="none" width="1561" height="60" x="0" y="220"></rect><g is="true" transform="translate(72,514)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-394"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(589,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(522,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-73"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(60,-411)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-394"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(589,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(522,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C4"></use></g></g></g></g></g></g><use xlink:href="#MJSZ2-29" x="2398" y="-1"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2996,877)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">π</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></mrow></mfrac><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">m</mi><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace></mrow><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">M</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><mi is="true">S</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Δ</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">s</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Δ</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">π</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></mrow></mfrac><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">m</mi><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace></mrow><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">M</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><mi is="true">S</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Δ</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">s</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Δ</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where, <em>τ</em> represents the duration of the pulse; <em>m</em><sub>B</sub>, <em>V</em><sub>m</sub> and <em>M</em><sub>B</sub> denote the mass of the electrode (mg), the molar volume (cm<sup>3</sup> mol<sup>−1</sup>), and the molar mass of the anode materials (g mol<sup>−1</sup>), respectively; <em>S</em> is the geometric surface area of the electrode (cm<sup>2</sup>); Δ<em>E<sub>τ</sub></em> signifies the variation in potential (V) during the pulse, and Δ<em>E</em><sub>s</sub> refers to the steady-state potential difference (V).</div></section></section><section id="s0040"><h2 id="st065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085">Hydrothermal synthesis is widely used to prepare a variety of high-performance electrode materials due to its simple experimental equipment and clear growth mechanisms. With the increasing demand for high-performance sodium-ion battery anodes, there is a growing focus on fabricating various electrode composite materials on conductive substrates, such as TiO<sub>2</sub>/graphene <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a> and MoS<sub>2</sub>/graphene <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>. According to crystal growth theory, to achieve uniform growth of oxides or carbides particles on conductive substrates, it is essential to effectively suppress random nucleation on the substrate <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>, as this phenomenon often increases the size of the formed particles, which is not conducive to designing high-performance electrodes. Therefore, precise control over nucleation and growth during the hydrothermal preparation process is particularly important. Unfortunately, there is currently a lack of comparative studies in this area.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090">As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>, we have achieved the uniform growth of carbide nanocrystal heterojunctions on rGO nanosheets. In this case, glucose utilizes its abundant OH<sup>–</sup> on GO sheets to induce the uniform transformation of the molybdenum source precursor ammonium molybdate into MoO<sub>2</sub>, which is a key step in preparing the superstructural rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO composite nanosheets. This differs from the traditional structures (mixed, wrapped, or anchored models) formed by conventional crystal-oriented growth methods <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>. Pristine graphene is chemically stable, and metal oxides typically grow only at defects, such as oxygen functional groups, forming discontinuous island-like structures to minimize adverse contact between graphene and oxides <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a). Through glucose-induced nucleation, we achieved heterogeneous and uniform nucleation of MoO<sub>2</sub> on GO sheets, avoiding the spontaneous formation of independent coarse particles. Subsequent annealing processes facilitated the topological transition of MoO<sub>2</sub> between graphene layers to Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC, and the GO was converted into reduced graphene oxide (rGO) through thermal treatment, ultimately forming superstructural rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO composite nanosheets (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>b). Understanding and controlling the role of glucose in the construction of superstructures is the key to optimizing electrode structure and performance. This study will continue to pay attention in the later work.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr1.jpg" height="464" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (471KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (471KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <strong>Illustration of the concept of glucose-mediated uniform nucleation of precursors.</strong> (a) Illustration of the impact of glucose on the nucleation and growth rates of crystal formation. The addition of glucose facilitates uniform nucleation of the precursor on the graphene surface, enhancing the formation of MoO<sub>2</sub> nanocrystals within the confined space of GO. (b) A comparison between the traditional method of synthesizing MoO<sub>2</sub> nanocrystals on graphene and the proposed crystallographic-oriented growth model, which enables the uniform deposition of MoO<sub>2</sub> nanocrystals and the formation of a superstructure arrangement.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0095"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a illustrates the preparation schematic of the superstructural anodes. To investigate the effect of glucose on the formation of the superstructure, we conducted corresponding control experiments. Compared to the samples without glucose, shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b and c, the superstructural anodes morphologies prepared by our proposed glucose-induced process exhibit significant differences. The samples without glucose appear in an aggregated form, whereas those with added glucose display a distinct sandwich-like layered structure (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d–f).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr2.jpg" height="586" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (986KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (986KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <strong>The preparation procedure and structural characterization of as-prepared superstructural rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO.</strong> (a) Schematic representation of preparation pathway for superstructural rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO. (b, c) FESEM images of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC. (d, e, f) FESEM images of rGO- Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO at various magnifications. (g) XRD patterns of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100">To elucidate the crystal structure of active materials in the superstructure, we conducted XRD tests on two samples, one with glucose addition and one without. The results showed that the XRD diffraction peaks of both samples were almost identical, containing two crystal phases: Mo<sub>2</sub>C (PDF: 77–0720) and MoC (PDF: 89–4305), as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g. To further understand the transformation process of Mo<sub>2</sub>C and MoC, we also performed XRD analysis on these two samples before heat treatment (as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>a). The results indicated that both samplesbefore heat treatment contained the MoO<sub>2</sub> (PDF: 86–0135) crystal phase. Based on these experimental results, we can reasonably infer that the Mo<sub>2</sub>C and MoC in the samples after heat treatment were derived from MoO<sub>2</sub>. This transformation undoubtedly benefited from the presence of graphene in the samples and the heat treatment under N<sub>2</sub> atmosphere, which together provided a reducing environment, ultimately promoting the reduction of MoO<sub>2</sub> to Mo<sub>2</sub>C and MoC. Furthermore, we conducted SEM observations on the glucose-added sample before heat treatment (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>b). The results showed that this sample had a very similar microstructure to the superstructure sample after heat treatment, both exhibiting a typical sandwich structure. This finding indicates that a topological transformation occurred during the heat treatment process, namely from rGO-MoO<sub>2</sub>-rGO to rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105">To uncover the intricate architecture of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO, we conducted an in-depth TEM examination (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a–e). The observations in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a and b revealed that minute nanoparticles, approximately 13&nbsp;nm in diameter, were evenly dispersed across the entire rGO matrix. The SAED depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c confirmed the presence of diffraction rings corresponding to both MoC and Mo<sub>2</sub>C. The HRTEM image presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d showcased the crystalline lattices of MoC (006) and Mo<sub>2</sub>C (211), indicating a distinct interface between the two crystal phases, which were tightly integrated. These findings suggest that the Mo<sub>2</sub>C and MoC phases, as identified in the XRD analysis, coalesce to form a heterojunction structure, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d. Furthermore, elemental mapping, as seen in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e, demonstrated the even distribution of molybdenum (Mo), carbon (C), and nitrogen (N) throughout the entire composite material.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr3.jpg" height="632" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. <strong>Examination of the microstructures and XPS analysis of superstructural rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO.</strong> (a, b) TEM images of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO. (c) SAED patterns of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO. (d) HRTEM images of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO. (e) the element mapping images showing the distribution of C, N, Mo within in the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO sample. (f) Raman spectra of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC. (g) BET and pore size distribution for rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC. XPS spectra of (h) C 1&nbsp;s, (i) N 1&nbsp;s and (j) Mo 3d for rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">The Raman spectra presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f for rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO reveal two distinct peaks at 814 and 993&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>, which correspond to the A<sub>1g</sub> and A<sub>g</sub> vibrational modes characteristic of MoC and Mo<sub>2</sub>C, respectively. Furthermore, the peaks observed at 1350 and 1580&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> are indicative of the D and G bands, which are typical of the carbon matrix. Notably, the <em>I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub></em> ratio for rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO is marginally lower than that for rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC, with a ratio of 1.10 compared to 1.24, suggesting a higher degree of graphitic order, which is beneficial for enhanced electrical conductivity. Furthermore, it was observed that the Raman peak intensities for MoC and Mo<sub>2</sub>C in rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO are considerably higher than those in rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC, signifying an improved crystallinity of the Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC heterojunction within the highly graphitized graphene framework. Additionally, it is observed that the GO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO composites exhibited a considerably higher specific surface area, reaching up to 197&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>, which significantly surpassed the specific surface area of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC, which is merely 24&nbsp;m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>. The pore size distribution analysis (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>g and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a>) corroborates the presence of a pronounced mesoporous structure within the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO composites. The discrepancy in specific surface area between these two composites is closely tied to their structural differences. In comparison to the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC composite, the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO, which features a distinctive superstructure, exhibits a distinct advantage in terms of its high specific surface area. This advantage is likely linked to the inherent ion-conducting channels associated with the superstructure's architecture <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115">The chemical environment and valence states of the elements Mo, C, and N within the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO were investigated using XPS. The Mo 3d XPS spectrum for rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO displays three main peaks at binding energies of approximately 232.3, 229.6, and 228.9&nbsp;eV (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>j) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>. These peaks can be assigned to Mo<sup>4+</sup> 3d<sub>3/2</sub>, Mo<sup>4+</sup> 3d<sub>5/2</sub>, and Mo<sup>2+</sup> 3d<sub>5/2</sub>, respectively, while the peak at 236&nbsp;eV corresponding to Mo<sup>6+</sup> 3d<sub>3/2</sub> is attributed to the unavoidable oxidation of Mo<sub>2</sub>C during the XPS measurement under ambient air conditions. The high-resolution C 1&nbsp;s XPS spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>h) can be deconvoluted into three distinct peaks, which are associated with non-oxygenated graphitic carbon in sp<sup>2</sup> hybridization at 284.8&nbsp;eV, C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N carbon in sp<sup>3</sup> hybridization at 285.8&nbsp;eV, and carbonyl C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">O carbon at 288.6&nbsp;eV. It is noteworthy that the C 1&nbsp;s spectrum particularly highlights the enhanced intensity of sp<sup>2</sup> carbon in C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">C bonds relative to other chemical bonds, this observation suggests that the carbon material in the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anodes following the post-annealing treatment exhibits a notable graphite—like character. This finding is supported by previous studies <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">The N within the composite originates from <em>N</em>-doped carbon, which is formed through the carbonization of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) at elevated temperatures. The N doping is known to enhance the electrical conductivity of the amorphous carbon component <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>i presents peaks at 401.5, 398.7, and 394.9&nbsp;eV, which correspond to pyrrolic-N (N-5), graphitic N (<em>N</em>-Q), and Mo 3p<sub>3/2</sub>, respectively. XPS peak fitting results of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and their binding energies and assignments, as shown in Tab S2. These observations further substantiate the presence of <em>N</em>-doped carbon material in the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO composite.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0125">CV measurements were performed on both the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anodes at a scan rate of 0.1&nbsp;mV/s, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>a. For the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode, the initial cathodic scan featured a peak at 0.22&nbsp;V, which can be attributed to the formation of a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer through the insertion of excess Na<sup>+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. Compared with rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anodes, the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO exhibited two distinct cathodic peaks at 0.1&nbsp;V and 0.37&nbsp;V during the initial cathodic scan, which are indicative of a reversible Na<sup>+</sup> insertion and extraction process, indicating a multistep Na<sup>+</sup> uptake process.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr4.jpg" height="581" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (780KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (780KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>. Evaluation of the electrochemical Na<sup>+</sup> storage capabilities of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode.</strong> (a) Cyclic voltammetry (CV) profiles for the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO electrode at a scan rate of 0.1&nbsp;mV/s. (b) Galvanostatic charge–discharge curves for the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode at a current density of 0.2 A/g, spanning from 0.01&nbsp;V to 2.8&nbsp;V, for the initial ten cycles. (c) Galvanostatic charge–discharge profiles at varying current densities from 0.1-10 A/g for the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode. (d, e) Comparison of long-term cycling performance for two anodes at 0.2 and 1 A/g, respectively. (f) Rate capabilities of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anodes from 0.1-10 A/g. (g) Comparison of the rate capability of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode with other anodes reported in the literature.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">The GCD curves for the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode at 0.2 A/g exhibited an initial discharge/charge capacity of 778/388&nbsp;mAh/g, which corresponds to a low initial Coulombic efficiency of 49.9&nbsp;%, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b. This reduced efficiency is typically due to the formation of a SEI film during the initial cycle, which results in the irreversible consumption and decomposition of the electrolyte <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. However, by the second cycle, the Coulombic efficiency improved significantly to 88.5&nbsp;% with a discharge/charge capacity of 322/285&nbsp;mAh/g. After ten cycles, the capacities stabilized at 263/259&nbsp;mAh/g, and the Coulombic efficiency further increased to 98.5&nbsp;%, indicating excellent cyclic stability.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">The rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode also demonstrated superior rate performance at various current densities ranging from 0.1 to 10 A/g, delivering specific capacities of 301, 252, 212, 171, 122, 78, and 41&nbsp;mAh/g, respectively, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c. Notably, the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode showed significantly higher specific capacity when compared to the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>b and c). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d and e presents the long-term cycling performance of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode when discharged-charged at 0.2 and 1 A/g, respectively. Compared with Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO, the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode displays a higher reversible capacity than the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anodes (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>). It can still deliver a discharge capacity of 106&nbsp;mAh/g after 5000 cycles at 1 A/g, indicating its excellent cycling stability. The significantly enhanced sodium-ion storage performance of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode may be attributed to the synergistic enhancement of electron and sodium-ion transport kinetics, which could benefit from the internal electric field within the heterojunction interface <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140">Furthermore, the Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC heterojunction nanoparticles within the interlayers of rGO are effectively stabilized by the rGO matrix, which minimizes the tendency for Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC heterojunction nanocrystals to aggregate and ensures structural integrity. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>f presents the rate capability of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode, demonstrating that it is capable of delivering specific capacities of 301, 252, 212, 171, 122, 78, and 41mAh/g at various current densities ranging from 0.1 to 10.0 A/g. Moreover, upon reducing the current density back to 0.1 A/g, the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode sustains its high specific capacity, regaining a reversible capacity of 230&nbsp;mAh/g, which is indicative of its efficient ion and electron transport properties. In contrast, the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anode exhibits considerably lower capacities of 246, 190, 140, 77, 46, 32, and 16&nbsp;mAh/g at the same series of current densities, which are substantially less than those observed for the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode. A comparison of the rate performance of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode with the state-of-the-art results from the literature on Mo-based systems is provided in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>g and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S3</span></span></a>. The capacity of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode and high-rate capabilities are notably superior to most anodes reported for SIBs, and the long cycle performance is better (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S4</span></span></a>). This outstanding performance suggests that the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode is a promising candidate for use as an anode in SIBs applications.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0145">To gain a deeper insight into the electrochemical behavior, the kinetic mechanisms of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anodes were further explored. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a and d illustrate the CV curves for the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anodes, respectively, at a range of scan rates from 0.2 to 1.0&nbsp;mV/s. The area enclosed by the CV curves corresponds to the charge storage that arises from both faradaic and nonfaradaic processes <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0285" name="bb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0290" name="bb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a>. This phenomenon can be described by the power-law relationship <em>i</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;<em>aν<sup>b</sup></em>, where <em>ν</em> represents the scan rate, and <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are empirical parameters. The exponent <em>b</em> in the plot of log <em>i</em> versus log <em>ν</em> is a pivotal factor in discerning the nature of the redox process; <em>a</em>, <em>b</em> value of 1 is indicative of non-diffusion controlled surface redox reactions, whereas <em>a</em>, <em>b</em> value of 0.5 is characteristic of an ideal diffusion-controlled faradaic process <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0295" name="bb0295" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[59]</span></span></a>. The kinetic analysis reveals that the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode demonstrates a synergistic blend of diffusion-controlled battery-like processes and surface-controlled capacitive behavior <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>. For the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode, the cathodic peak <em>b</em> values were found to be 0.8 and the anodic peak <em>b</em> values were 0.9 within the scan rate range of 0.2 to 1.0&nbsp;mV/s, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>g. In contrast, under the same scanning conditions, the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anode showed marginally reduced cathodic peak <em>b</em> values of 0.64 and anodic peak <em>b</em> values of 0.95, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>i. These specific <em>b</em> values confirm the superior electrochemical performance of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO composite anode. The overall current response (<em>i</em>) at a particular potential (V) can be decomposed into two components: the pseudocapacitive contribution and the intercalation contribution, as delineated by the following equation. Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0015" name="be0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(3)</span></span></a> is a reformulation derived from the underlying Eq. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#e0010" name="be0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="e0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">(2)</span></span></a>.<span is="true">i</mi><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mfrac is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mn is="true">2</mn></mfrac></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-2"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mfrac is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mn is="true">2</mn></mfrac></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span><span class="display"><span id="e0015" class="formula"><span class="label">(3)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-3-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>log</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>10</mn></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot;
