linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">log</mi><mn is="true">10</mn></msub><mi is="true">a</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi is="true">b</mi><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">log</mi><mn is="true">10</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-3"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">log</mi><mn is="true">10</mn></msub><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">log</mi><mn is="true">10</mn></msub><mi is="true">a</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi is="true">b</mi><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">log</mi><mn is="true">10</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr5.jpg" height="953" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. <strong>Analysis of the electrochemical kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup> storage in the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode.</strong> (a, d) CV curves for rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anodes at varying scan rate. (b, e) the pseudocapacitive contribution (red region) to the total current of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC at a scan rate of 0.4&nbsp;mV/s. (c, f) percentage of the capacitive contributions d at different scan rates of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC. (g, i) plots of logarithm peak current versus logarithm of scan rate for rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC. (h, j) the triad of sodium ion accommodation mechanisms within materials, and the interrelation pertaining to the quantity of sodium ions harnessed by each method.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">In this context, the coefficients <em>k</em><sub>1</sub>ν and <em>k</em><sub>2</sub>ν<sup>1/2</sup> signify the contributions to the current from capacitive and insertion processes, respectively. These factors enable the differentiation between the current responses attributable to each process at a specified potential <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0300" name="bb0300" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0300"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[60]</span></span></a>. As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b and e, the shaded region delineates the voltage profile that is associated with the current response originating from the capacitive effects. This shaded region is then juxtaposed with the overall measured current within a standard CV curve, which is obtained for both the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anodes at a scanning velocity of 0.4&nbsp;mV s<sup>−1</sup>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155">At a scan rate of 0.4&nbsp;mV s<sup>−1</sup>, the partition of diffusional and capacitive contributions to the electrode's current is illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b, with the red segment signifying the portion attributable to capacitive effects, which amounts to 83&nbsp;%. Through an analogous evaluation, the capacitive contribution for the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anode at this scan rate is determined to be 58&nbsp;%, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>e. Upon elevating the scan rate from 0.2 to 1&nbsp;mV s<sup>−1</sup>, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c, the proportion of capacitive contribution progressively ascends from 69&nbsp;% to 90&nbsp;%, surpassing that of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anode, as observed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>f. In conclusion, these findings indicate that the layered configuration of MoC and Mo<sub>2</sub>C within the electrode architecture can significantly augment the capacitive behavior, facilitate the transfer of electrons and migration of ions, and subsequently, elevate the kinetics of electrochemical reactions <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160">Upon conducting a comparative analysis of the electrochemical tests, has revealed that the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anodes exhibit performance behaviors that are not constrained by diffusion limitations, contrasting with the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC electrode. When examining ion storage mechanisms, they can typically be categorized into three types: surface storage, bulk storage, and interface storage, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>j. The term “diffusion control” implies that the ion storage behavior is predominantly restricted by the rate at which ions diffuse through the electrode material <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0305" name="bb0305" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0305"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[61]</span></span></a>. In such a scenario, the rate of Na<sup>+</sup> intercalation and extraction is entirely contingent upon their diffusion coefficient within the Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anodes.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0165">In contrast, “non-diffusion-limited” suggests that the ion storage process is not exclusively dictated by the diffusion process <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0290" name="bb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0310" name="bb0310" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0310"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[62]</span></span></a>. Instead, it may also be affected by other factors, such as the rate of charge transfer reactions at the electrode surface, the structural integrity of the electrode, and the ionic conductivity of the electrolyte. Under non-diffusion-limited conditions, the rate at which ions are intercalated and extracted can potentially surpass the rate.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0170">Under non-diffusion-limited conditions, the rate of ionintercalation and extraction mayexceed that observed under diffusion-controlled conditions. Drawing from these analyses, the characteristics of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO electrode pertaining to non-diffusion limited aspects are presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>h. These include mechanisms of storage at the surface and the interface, which contribute to the electrode's overall performance.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0175">Additionally, the GITT was employed to investigate the diffusion kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup> within the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anodes, as depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a and b. This suggests a faster diffusion rate of Na<sup>+</sup> in the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode. Moreover, to assess the electrochemical polarization and the capability of Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion, specific points on the discharge plateaus, around 0.5&nbsp;V, were selected for further analysis, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c and d. The results demonstrated that the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode exhibited lower values of <em>IR</em> drop, Δ<em>E</em><sub>t</sub> (overpotential), and Δ<em>E</em><sub>s</sub> (difference in entropy) when compared to the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anode <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0315" name="bb0315" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0315"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[63]</span></span></a>. This lower <em>IR</em> drop signifies that the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode has a reduced internal resistance and can facilitate the rapid transport of Na<sup>+</sup> during the discharge process. This is attributed to its stabilized sandwich-structured architecture, which enhances the ionic and electronic conductivity of the electrode material. In summary, the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode demonstrated an improved kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion, evidenced by an increased diffusion coefficient, and an overall enhanced electrochemical performance. The reduced internal resistance and the ability to expedite Na<sup>+</sup> shuttling contribute to its superior performance as SIBs anodes.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr6.jpg" height="381" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (316KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (316KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. <strong>GITT potential profiles for three distinct anodes:</strong> rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO (a), and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC (b). (c) and (d) represent the potential profiles corresponding to each individual GITT step, respectively.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0180">The use of EIS enable the elucidation of the kinetic processes involved in the electrochemical reactions. The Nyquist plots for both the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO and rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anodes are presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>. These plots typically exhibit a semicircle at high frequencies, indicative of charge transfer resistance and ohmic resistance. At low frequencies, a linear segment is observed, associated with Warburg impedance, reflecting ion diffusion within the anode material. The Nyquist plot for the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode exhibited a smaller semicircle in comparison to that of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anode, indicating a lower charge transfer resistance. This is consistent with the sandwich structure of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode, which facilitates electron transfer from Na<sup>+</sup> and consequently enhances its conductivity <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0305" name="bb0305" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0305"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[61]</span></span></a>. Tab. S5 details the impedance parameters for both anodes. The <em>R</em><sub>ct</sub> for the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode, derived from the EIS data, was approximately 64.3&nbsp;Ω, which is significantly lower than that of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC anode, which had an <em>R</em><sub>ct</sub> of 126.8&nbsp;Ω, as depicted in the inset of <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>. This lower <em>R</em><sub>ct</sub> for the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode implies a higher electrochemical reactivity and faster Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion, which can be ascribed to its reduced charge transfer resistance and the improved electronic conductivity of the material.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0185">To gain a deeper understanding of the kinetic mechanisms responsible for the superior electrochemical performance observed in the distinctively structured rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anodes, we selected 12 characteristic voltage points throughout the initial charge–discharge cycle, spanning from a discharge voltage of 1.9&nbsp;V to a charge voltage of 2.8&nbsp;V, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>a. Subsequently, <em>ex situ</em> XRD (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>b) and Raman spectroscopy analyses on the electrode material. It is crucial to note that when exploring the mechanisms behind the performance enhancement, it is insufficient to consider the initial design of the electrode. Although the 2D planar confinement of graphene within the electrode architecture facilitates electron transfer within the Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC active material and limits excessive interaction with the electrolyte, thus minimizing side reactions <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0320" name="bb0320" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0320"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[64]</span></span></a>, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>d, the precise transformations occurring within the active Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC material during the charge–discharge cycle remain to be fully understood. Consequently, the <em>ex situ</em> XRD and Raman analyses offer a more granular, microscopic insight into the correlation between the electrode's structural attributes and its electrochemical performance.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr7.jpg" height="529" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (748KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (748KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0035"><p id="sp0050"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. <strong>The working mechanism of Na<sup>+</sup> storage of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anodes in SIBs.</strong> (a) The first charge–discharge profile of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode. (b) <em>Ex situ</em> XRD patterns of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO electrode at different charge–discharge stages. (c) <em>Ex situ</em> Raman spectra of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anodes at different charge–discharge depths. (d, e) Schematic representation of Na<sup>+</sup> storage mechanism for rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO composite anodes.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0190">During the charge–discharge process of anodes, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>b, <em>Ex situ</em> XRD analysis revealed that diffraction peaks cycled rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anodes are similar to those of the two phases, Mo<sub>2</sub>C (PDF: 77–0720) and MoC (PDF: 894305), in original rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anodes sample (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g). It is particularly noteworthy that, compared with the diffraction peaks of Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g, the <em>Ex situ</em> XRD in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>b shows that most of the diffraction peaks of anodes have experienced slight shifts. According to previous first-principles and experimental studies, Mo<sub>2</sub>C and MoC undergo intercalation reactions during the discharge process, transforming into Na<sub>x</sub>Mo<sub>2</sub>C and Na<sub>x</sub>MoC, respectively. The results of our experiment are in accordance with those of previous studies in this field. Based on the XRD test results, it is indicated that the Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC nanocrystal heterojunctions intercalated between graphene layers play an important role in Na<sup>+</sup> storage, which is crucial for enhancing the specific capacity of the composite anodes.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0195">The <em>Ex situ</em> Raman spectroscopy analysis results during the charge–discharge process of anode are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>c. It is evident that the typical D and G bands of graphene at different charge–discharge stages of anode have not changed significantly. However, it is interesting to note that there is a clear boundary in the peak within the wave number range of 813–935&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> before and after the end of discharge. Specifically, before discharge, the positions of the three peaks at 829, 869, and 935&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> of the anode are almost the same; after the end of discharge and the start of charge, the positions of the other three peaks of the electrode, namely 813, 840, and 890&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>, are also consistent. Further analysis indicates that these six peaks are all attributed to the stretching vibration peaks of Mo-C in Mo<sub>2</sub>C and MoC <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0325" name="bb0325" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0325"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[65]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0330" name="bb0330" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0330"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[66]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0335" name="bb0335" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0335"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[67]</span></span></a>. The shift of the peaks reflects the change in the vibration frequency of the Mo-C bond, and the root cause of this change is the alteration of the local environment of Mo-C, indicating that Na<sup>+</sup> participate in the formation of Mo-C-Na bonds during the charge–discharge process. <em>Ex situ</em> Raman spectroscopy further confirms from a local perspective that the Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC nanocrystal heterojunctions intercalated between graphene layers are involved in Na<sup>+</sup> storage.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0200">The advantages of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO composite material as a SIBs anode are self-evident. The successful preparation of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode with unique structure demonstrates excellent electrochemical performance, mainly due to: (1) The unique sandwich structure of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode has significant advantages in Na<sup>+</sup> storage. The Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC nanocrystals wrapped by double-layer rGO not only serve as efficient Na<sup>+</sup> storage, but also act as a 2D conductive network to enhance electron transfer and Na<sup>+</sup> transport; in addition, the ultra-small Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC heterostructure nanocrystals further accelerate the kinetic reaction (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>d). (2) It is particularly emphasized that when Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC generates Na<sub>x</sub>Mo<sub>2</sub>C and Na<sub>x</sub>MoC through intercalation reactions, the slight lattice volume expansion is confined between the two layers of rGO, where rGO plays a role in buffering stress. At the same time, during the Na<sup>+</sup> intercalation/de-intercalation process, the volume fluctuation also leads to an increase in the interlayer spacing of rGO, thereby providing more storage space for Na<sup>+</sup>, which helps to achieve excellent electrochemical performance, especially in terms of rate performance. (3) The layered structure of rGO and its significant specific surface area provide a wealth of active sites for Na<sup>+</sup> storage, ensuring excellent storage capacity. This unique structure also confers the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode with excellent rate and cycle performance, thereby substantiating its considerable potential in the domain of electrochemical energy storage.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0205">Because of the good electrochemical performance of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO in the half-cell, and to explore the practical application prospects of the material, sodium ion full-cell is assembled using rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO as the anode and Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> as the cathode. The rate performance of the full cell is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>a, where when the current density is 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, and 5.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>, the average discharge specific capacity is 191.6, 175.6, 156.3, 141, 122.5, and 86.7 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively. It is worth noting that the specific capacity reaches 180.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> when the current density is restored to 0.1 A g<sup>−1</sup>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>b depicts a full cell cycling at 1 A g<sup>−1</sup>. It can be seen that for the initial charge/discharge, the specific capacity of the battery is 160.4/136.5 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, which corresponds to an ICE of 85.09&nbsp;%. The cycle performances was measured at 1.0 A g<sup>−1</sup>, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>c, where the reversible capacity was maintained at 108.4 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 500 cycles. The excellent electrochemical performance of rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cell has promising prospects in future SIB applications. Furthermore, a single coin cell made by this Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode and the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO anode was enough to lighten a light-emitting diode (LED), as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0040" name="bf0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>d. The results unequivocally indicate that the sodium ion full-cell, which utilizes rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO as an anode material, possesses significant and widespread practical applications in daily life.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0040"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr8.jpg" height="568" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0040"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (463KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (463KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979724019714-gr8.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0040"><p id="sp0055"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. <strong>Electrochemical performances of the rGO-Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC-rGO//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> Sodium-ion full cells.</strong> (a) Rate performances of sodium-ion full cell at a series of current density capacitance. (b) Discharge/charge curves at the current density of 1 A/g. (c) Cycling performances at a current density of 1 A/g. (d) The photograph of an LED lighted by one sodium ion full-cell.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0045"><h2 id="st070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0210">In summary, our work has introduced a novel Mo<sub>2</sub>C/MoC heterojunction nanocrystals-graphene superstructure for SIBs anodes, highlighting the significant potential of heterostructure integration with conductive materials to enhance conversion kinetics. The innovative preparation method using glucose-induced nucleation of molybdenum precursors on GO, coupled with hydrothermal and thermal treatments, has resulted in a superstructure that embeds heterojunction nanocrystals within a graphene matrix. Such superstructure maximizes the utilization of active anodes, alleviates volume variation, and permits complete charge–discharge process. The resultant anode material demonstrates impressive specific capacity and long-term cycling stability, overcoming the usual trade-offs between capacity and durability. This superstructural configuration and superior performance provide a strong incentive for the development of high-performance SIBs.</div></section><section id="s0050"><h2 id="st075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0215"><strong>Hua Feng:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Data curation. <strong>Bin Zhang:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Validation, Methodology. <strong>Yanzi Lei:</strong> Investigation. <strong>Luyao Luo:</strong> Validation, Resources. <strong>Danling Zhang:</strong> Data curation. <strong>Dawei Chai:</strong> Methodology, Investigation. <strong>Kuang Xu:</strong> Formal analysis. <strong>Jiling Mo:</strong> Formal analysis. <strong>Hai Wang:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision, Funding acquisition.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st080" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0220">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st085" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgments</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0225">This work was financially supported by <span id="gp005">National Natural Science Foundation of China</span> (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12264006</span></span></a>), Guangxi Natural Science Foundation (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2023GXNSFAA026352</span></span></a>), and the Central Government Guidance Funds for Local Scientific and Technological Development, China (No. Guike <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">ZY22096024</span></span></a>), and the Innovation Project of Guangxi <span id="gp015">Graduate Education</span> (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">YCSW2023193</span></span></a>).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="s0060"><h2 id="st095" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85129285421&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0335"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=In%20situ%20phase%20transition%20induced%20TM-MoCMo2C%20%20heterostructure%20catalysts%20for%20efficient%20hydrogen%20evolution&amp;publication_year=2022&amp;author=J.%20Li&amp;author=R.%20Ge&amp;author=P.%20Lan&amp;author=J.%20Yang&amp;author=J.%20Feng&amp;author=Y.%20Li&amp;author=S.%20Li&amp;author=B.%20Liu&amp;author=W.%20Li" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0335"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (2)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0925838825015506"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Construction of CoFe&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;/TiO&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;@C S-scheme heterojunction and removal of phenol by activated peroxymonosulfate</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Alloys and Compounds</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0050">S-type heterojunctions can suppress the recombination of photogenerated charges during the photocatalytic reaction in a photocatalyst, creating favorable conditions for separation and transport of the photogenerated carriers and thereby enhancing the redox ability of the photocatalyst. Herein, TiO<sub>2</sub>@C was formed via in situ oxidation (calcination) of Ti<sub>3</sub>C<sub>2</sub>, then followed by the hydrothermal method, establishing a CoFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>@C photocatalyst with an S-type heterojunction between TiO<sub>2</sub>@C and CoFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>. The CoFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>@C photocatalyst removed phenol more efficiently than CoFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> and TiO<sub>2</sub>@C, degrading 80 % (40 mg/L) of phenol within 15 min under simulated solar-light irradiation in the presence of peroxymonosulfate. Moreover, CoFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>/TiO<sub>2</sub>@C and was easily magnetically separated with high recovery. Free-radical trapping experiments confirmed that <strong>·</strong>O<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup>, <sup>1</sup>O<sub>2</sub>, and SO<sub>4</sub><sup><strong>·</strong>−</sup> are the main activators of phenol removal. Along with liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry, the free-radical trapping experiments revealed the possible degradation pathway and photocatalytic degradation mechanism of phenol. The photocatalyst also exhibited remarkable photocatalytic activity and stability, demonstrating its potential applicability in phenol treatment.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0925838825013829"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Trace graphene oxide and silver synergistically modify the microstructure and electrical contact properties of Al&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;-Cu/35Mo composites</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Alloys and Compounds</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0105">The design and preparation of electric contact materials with excellent arc erosion resistance has always been a challenge. In this study, we synergistically introduced Ag and GO into Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-Cu/35Mo composites using rapid hot-press sintering method, resulting in a structurally homogeneous composite with excellent thermal conductivity, and a density of up to 99 %. The arc erosion resistance of composites was investigated with the JF04C contact material test system. The results indicated that the 0.3Ag/0.3GO/Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>-Cu/35Mo composite have lower arc energy, arc duration, welding force and more stable contact resistance. The uniform dispersion of γ-Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles generated by internal oxidation and the Ag dissolved in the Cu matrix improved the overall mechanical properties of the composite materials. The in-situ generation of MoC/Mo<sub>2</sub>C heterostructures at the Cu-Mo interface with the addition of GO, which improves the interfacial bonding and enhances the resistance of the composites to arc erosion.</div></div></div></div></li></ul></div></div></section></div><div class="Footnotes text-xs"><dl class="footnote"><dt class="footnote-label"><a class="anchor u-padding-s-hor u-padding-xs u-display-inline-block anchor-primary" href="#bfn1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><sup>1</sup></span></span></a></dt><dd class="footnote-detail u-padding-xs-top"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="np005">co-first authors.</div></dd></dl><dl class="footnote"><dt class="footnote-label"><a class="anchor u-padding-s-hor u-padding-xs u-display-inline-block anchor-primary" href="#bfn2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><sup>2</sup></span></span></a></dt><dd class="footnote-detail u-padding-xs-top"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="np010">Hua Feng and Bin Zhang contributed equally to this work.</div></dd></dl></div><a class="anchor abstract-link anchor-primary" href="/science/article/abs/pii/S0021979724019714"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View Abstract</span></span></a><div class="Copyright"><span class="copyright-line">© 2024 Elsevier Inc. All rights are reserved, including those for text and data mining, AI training, and similar technologies.</span></div></article><div class="u-display-block-from-md col-lg-6 col-md-8 pad-right href="/science/article/pii/S2405829718300102" title="Intercalation Na-ion storage in two-dimensional MoS2-xSex and capacity enhancement by selenium substitution"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Intercalation Na-ion storage in two-dimensional MoS<sub>2-x</sub>Se<sub>x</sub> and capacity enhancement by selenium substitution</span></span></span></a></h3><div class="article-source u-clr-grey6"><div class="source">Energy Storage Materials, Volume 14, 2018, pp. 136-142</div></div><div class="authors"><span>Guichong</span> <span>Jia</span>, …, <span>Hong Jin</span> <span>Fan</span></div></div><div class="buttons"><a class="anchor anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829718300102/pdfft?md5=ff7b759e84240b7ae3f985d2c071ed76&amp;pid=1-s2.0-S2405829718300102-main.pdf" target="_blank" rel="nofollow" aria-describedby="recommended-articles-article4-title"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 35 32" height="20" class="icon icon-pdf-multicolor"><path d="M7 .362h17.875l6.763 6.1V31.64H6.948V16z"     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {

    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
